text:
I’ve been using FileTrees.jl quite a lot over the past couple of months, and am really liking it. I don’t know the python ecosystem well enough to be sure, but it looks like there isn’t any kind of high-level api with similar plan-optimization functionality in python land. (The python multiprocessing scripts I’ve seen seem to require more technical knowledge and tend not to be as compact.)

If this is indeed the case, I think that we should brag about FileTrees (and Dagger) more when talking about Julia’s advantages --- a lot of folks wanting to scale things up on a cluster tend not to have formal training in computer architecture etc, and this is the kind of thing that’d really appeal to them. (And it’d presumably make things quite a bit easier even for experienced folks.)

text: I agree, people should be bragging about our distributed computing story. It's mostly my fault that I haven't encouraged people to do that :smile:  I'm aiming to give a JuliaCon talk about using Dagger to build applications, so that should help encourage people to try it out.

text: After thinking a bit more about it, I think the point I wanted to make was this. *If* it is indeed much easier to do common sorts of distributed data wrangling with FileTrees than in Python, then that would show the following. Contrary to the oft-repeated claim that it’s only worth using Julia if you need to do custom things or need cutting-edge stuff in somewhat niche fields, Julia can in fact be helpful even for very run-of-the-mill things like reading a ton of xml files in your filetree and lazily wrangling them. You can do that with FileTrees without knowing much about computer architecture or distributed computing; and even if you do know all those things, you’d still be more productive using something higher-level like FileTrees
